text: Family Member: Right. Patient: Right, right, yeah. Doctor: So, so I just want to take a moment and pause and say we’ve got a serious problem here but it’s not a death sentence a year from now or two years from now. Patient: Right, right, right. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: Perspective. Patient: Yeah, yeah, yeah. Doctor: That’s one perspective, okay? Patient: Sure. Doctor: So the other thing, so we’ve got this fifty/fifty with the hormones and radiation. The question is what else can we do. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: So what else we can do is we can hit what’s remaining as far as the cancer really hard right now and when I say really hard what we’re talking about is some chemotherapy, um which we give you through the vein every three weeks and we give you four doses of it. It’s a medicine called Taxotere. And we add in um uh, if we can get insurance to pay for it, but generally we can; we add in a super-hormone medicine called ah Zytiga or Addaram. It’s a pill you take ah every day. It’s four pills every day.

text: Patient: Last week, yes, and my PSA jumped up tremendously. This is from last year. This is December and this is last week – up point five. Doctor: Blood count is good, tab - nothing dramatic – sporadic just below the normal range. So your kidney function goes up and down. So two months hundred at one point six, then it was repeated back down to one and then it was up at one point five. Where did you have your scan last week? Patient: In Hospital A in B___. I have the information and phone number. Doctor: So is G___ a new doctor for you or have you seen him for a while? Patient: No, that was only the second visit. And I saw him after, thoracic surgeon in Hospital B and spotted through tests, prostate cancer cells in my liver, and also on my lung Family Member: December. Patient: And that’s when he recommended I see an oncologist there. He teaches up here, too, so. He’s kind of the go-between. And he’s the one that said he’d work on the lung problem. Doctor: Just a couple more things So other than the CAT scan you haven’t had any other new scans? Patient: Not for I think about two months, three months, and I had the whole-body scan ordered by I think the thoracic surgeon V___ and that’s been the three lymph nodes on the lungs. Doctor: And that’s all you know from the last time you were here. Patient: Oh no, not since the last time I was here, no, just that one. Doctor: Okay, uh so the test results that we have is your ARV7 test. Dr. G but we had one- Patient: Uh hum.

text: Patient: - going down and coming back, and, uh, my daughter said you don’t seem like you feel anything. I said, no, I feel pretty good there. And, uh, so I do have those particular days, but then I have those days as well. I said, oh, man, when this day going to be over with so I can go to bed tonight Doctor: Is that because of pain that those days are hard for you? Patient: Sometimes it’s, it’s pain, but a lot of the areas that I wasn’t haven’t pain in, uh, not much anymore. My heel on my left side was having a lot of pain that I think I had shared, and, uh, I still have some if I go and overdo it, but other than that, no, my shoulders every now and then. My biggest challenge now is, is getting a good night’s sleep. Doctor: Okay. Patient: And that’s because I’ve tried a number of different ways on how to sleep in the bed. I, I have these pillows that I prop up with a long pillow there, to try to lean up against the back of it so, I, you know, my back is up against the pillow. It works some nights. Some nights it doesn’t work. Doctor: Okay. And so you’re having trouble falling asleep or is it that you fall asleep and then you, you’re waking up with-? Patient: Well, I wake back up. And sometimes if, uh, you know how you try to get in a comfortable position? It’s trying to find that comfortable position for that night. Doctor: So you’re waking up because of pain? Patient: Uh, not pain all the time. Sometimes it’s just, uh, what’s the term I’m looking for? Doctor: Discomfort? Patient: Yeah. You know? And, uh, just trying to get in a place where you feel like this is where I need to be at, I’m happy here. So, uh, uh, one of the best sleeping place, and I hate to say it, is my living room downstairs on the couch. I prop the pillows up, and, uh, and got my favorite space, so when I lay down and put my back up right up against the back of it, but I don’t want to be in the business of sleeping on my living room couch every night, either. We have a sleep number bed that we purchased just for this, but, uh, uh, I wouldn’t recommend sleep number being if that’s what you’re going, you’re going to use it for, because it’s not all it’s, it’s cut out to be. You’re paying a lot of money for a bed. And sometimes it works, sometimes it don’t. So my biggest challenge each night is to figure out, okay, what’s going to work tonight? Is my Lazy Boy going to work? Uh, I even tried the floor with my granddaughter’s, uh, what do you call those things she has? Family Member: The bean bag. Patient: The bean bags. That was the worst idea I ever had. When I got in that bean bag, uh, I, I was in pain. And the bad part is I couldn’t get back out of the, get out of the bean bag, and get off the floor.

text: Patient: Okay. Doctor: and you may opt out. For example, if you had say I just want to focus on treating that area let’s just do it Patient: Okay. Doctor: now one of the things that about the trial is that it’s randomized. Patient: Um, hum. Doctor: What does a randomized trial mean and in this particular case what are people are being randomized too. Randomized means that a computer and then essentially flips a coin and is random, very random in group A and group B of the clinical trial. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. So in this study there is a random allocation of the therapy and random also means that neither the physician which is me nor the patient which is you knows So it truly is random. And also the computer program flips the coin so to speak, you can only flip it once, you can’t continue to flip over and over until you get the condition you want Patient: Okay. Doctor: So option one is what we call observation. Your option two is the stereotactic radiotherapy, which I mentioned is called SBRT for short. that in order to make this trial a little more attractive to patients is designed ins such a way that the odds of getting the radiotherapy are twice as high as the odds of getting the observation. So in other words, you can think of it as a three-headed coin, there’s a one out of three chance that you’re gonna get the observation group. That’s about a thirty-three percent chance. And there’s a two out of three chance or sixty-six percent that you will get the stereotactic radiotherapy which most people on this trial want to get. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Okay. Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it.

Now if you get selected to go on the observation which is a one and three chance of that happening, the study was designed in such a way so that all patients eventually get the stereotactic radiotherapy because if you had a trial designed that way then people would not sign up for it.

text: Family Member: I may have to go sign an order. Doctor: He wrote down the questions? That’s pretty good. Family Member: Well, yeah. I mean, I am his daughter. (Laughs) Doctor: Does that mean it’s going to execute. I mean. Patient: I’m not as thorough as she is about things. My notes are really basic. Patient: Okay. What are some of the things that I should really be on the lookout for, the fatigue? Doctor: I think really just the tiredness. If you feel like you’re more off balance, you know, let’s say it’s weeks from now, that’s something also that’s pretty subtle that can come up just like that (snaps) Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’d have to make sure there’s, you know, nothing really going on but sometimes people feel a little bit off kilter. Patient: Vertigo, or-? Doctor: Uh, no. It’s almost just like, you know, you stand up and you’re ooh. Not like it’s spinning, but you just don’t have a sense of where you are, and then you right yourself, but, obviously, we don’t want you to fall. Um, so if you start to feel like, you know, there’s some unsteadiness, we need to know. Patient: Okay. Doctor: It’s a lot of paperwork if you fall.

text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: I must say that outside of a trial, I haven’t been that excited about the radium, to be honest, in the patients I’ve treated. Family Member: Why? Doctor: Uh, it’s been kind of toxic to the bone marrow. People have kind of gotten beat up when they take it and feeling really tired. Um, and in the trials where it got approved, uh, it didn’t really have big effects on the PSA. It didn’t have big effects on shrink, you know, changing the bone. The only readout was the people who got it seemed to live long. (Sound Door closes) Family Member: Okay. Doctor: So I think, you know, we- Patient: Is that how it works when they give, give the, uh, the seeds in the prostate? Is that, is that similar to that process? Doctor: But we haven’t done the seeds, uh, we just do them alone. But we haven’t, you know, probably somebody’s going to try that concept, which is seeds and some kind of immunotherapy as well. Patient: Oh, okay. Doctor: There has been, uh, some trials where what they did is they took a patient who has spots in the bone and radiated one spot and give it immunotherapy. There’s some signal that the immunotherapy works better when you do that. Uh, that you’re sort of damaging the cells with radiation and that seems to get your own immune system- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Kind of excited. Patient: Um hum.

text: Patient: It was cold. It was in the, in the thirties that night, but it’s back up in the seventies now. Doctor: Well you’re also in N__t so you’re used to that? Patient: Yeah. Yeah. Doctor: Do you, you have my phone information? Patient: I don’t think I have your e-mail. Doctor: Do you want it? Do you want a phone? I could use yours too. Okay? Uh, here’s my card. So my office is here. Well your phone number is in here. Just give it to me on the back of the card. Patient: It’s (gives phone number) Doctor: Okay. Patient: Thanks very much. Doctor: You’re welcome. Have a nice day.

text: Patient: Yeah, just out of the blue. It last for a few minutes and then stops. Doctor: Okay, on an average day how many times does that happen or is it not every day? Patient: When I’ve noticed it, it might be once or twice a day. Doctor: Okay, all right. Usually not at night, usually during the day. Patient: No, no. Well it could be the stress or the activity that’s happening in church that might push my level. Doctor: Well your testosterone level is still low. Patient: Uh hum. Doctor: And it’s creeping up, so about three or four months ago twice in the thirties. The normal testosterone for a man of your age would be around a hundred and fifty or two hundred. When we checked your last blood test about two weeks ago it had gone up to fifty-eight. Patient: Uh huh. Doctor: So it’s slowly increasing. Patient: Right. Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh.

Doctor: That would mean at least in theory that your fatigue should begin to get better, although the increase has been very recent, so it may not have given your body the time to adjust to that higher level of testosterone. And with time if you remain off of the hormone therapy like you’re currently doing despite your age it may continue to increase further. Patient: Uh huh.

text: Family Member: I had a question about if it does cause nausea (pause) Doctor: Yes. Family Member: Does that last the full three weeks or does it taper off? Doctor: Oh no. Most – I would not expect you to have significant nausea at all. I am going to give you a prescription on you know Zofran in case you need it. But most people don’t need more than what we give them today, right. Okay, so it’s not expected. Once in a while I guess if you have a major reaction, it’s okay to have it - Family Member: And so - Doctor: My hope is if this is a lot of this flare-up from the pain from the cancer, then actually we should start seeing an improvement ah without having to do - Patient: Well, that’s what I didn’t know was - Doctor: You know, and what raised my bar of suspicion is how much of this adrenal mass grew. Doctor: If the same kind of growth is happening in the bones, then you know it sort of took off all of a sudden, frankly. Family Member: Uh hum, right. Doctor: That made me think maybe the rest of your pain, also this big pain flare-up that you’re experiencing might be problematic Patient: Well see that’s - Doctor: But bone disease is always very hard to see.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
